header.title: The Scroll of Set (Issue Number 27, Volume III-3)

central_thesis: The Scroll of Set functions as the primary communication and intellectual forum for the Temple of Set, fostering individual self-creation (Xeper) and collective philosophical development within a decentralized Left Hand Path organization. It outlines the administrative and initiatory mechanics, emphasizing individual initiative and a dynamic, evolving doctrine distinct from traditional hierarchical models.

structure_content.summary: A mythological narrative, related by Bast, explaining an eclipse through the actions of Sekhmet, Ra, and Apep. It serves as an allegorical teaching for new Setians, emphasizing active protection of the Self (Ra) from destructive forces (Apep) and the cyclical nature of darkness/light as opportunities for magical work and growth.

This section by Robert Menschel I° highlights self-deception and rationalization as the most difficult obstacles to overcome in 'Setamorphosis.' It underscores the necessity of brutal self-honesty and piercing through one's own ploys as a critical step for authentic Setian evolution.

A quote from Anton Chekhov lamenting humanity's destructive tendencies towards the environment ('destroyed, not created'). This serves as a contrast or challenge to the Setian ethos of creative power and self-mastery, implicitly suggesting a Setian approach should be constructive and evolving.

Rosemary Kooiman II° questions the Temple of Set's stance on 'heresy,' comparing it to Catholic excommunication. The author seeks clarification on the balance between individual Xeper (intellectual growth) and adherence to established 'credos,' highlighting the tension between free thought and organizational cohesion within the Temple.

structure_content.chapter_title: [5] Report on the Santa Barbara Conclave
structure_content.summary: A detailed account by Glinda of a West Coast Conclave, covering social gatherings, rituals (Priesthood dinner, IV°+ Recognition, Conclave Ritual), administrative discussions (new Scroll policies), and the importance of face-to-face interaction for geographically dispersed Setians. It illustrates the practical community-building and administrative functions of the Temple.

structure_content.chapter_title: [6] The Scroll of Set in Theory & Practice
structure_content.summary: Michael A. Aquino V° articulates the fundamental purpose of The Scroll of Set: to be a 'free long-distance telephone conference-call' for the entire Temple membership, fostering discussion, sharing diverse ideas, and encouraging active contribution from members, rather than merely disseminating 'approved doctrine.' It is presented as an indispensable tool for 'Coming Into Being' and the 'third stage of evolution.'

structure_content.chapter_title: [7] New Administrative Systems for the Temple of Set
structure_content.summary: Michael A. Aquino V° announces the retirement of William F. Murray as Executive Director and details the redistribution of administrative responsibilities. Ronald K. Barrett will handle membership-related functions, and Margaret Wendall will manage insignia/supply/publications. This restructuring aims to alleviate pressures on individuals and better support the Temple's growth and members' Xeper.

structure_content.chapter_title: [8] First Steps Along the Left-Hand Path
structure_content.summary: Michael A. Aquino V° describes the evolving process for I° (Initiate) members to attain II° (Adept) Recognition. It outlines the evaluation criteria: raw intelligence, research/logical analysis, initiative, interaction with Priesthood (III°+), and individual projects. This section introduces the 'Crystal Tablet' as an essential 'orientation' text for I°s, designed to provide foundational Setian philosophy and address shortcomings of previous texts like The Satanic Bible.

Michael Waters III° strongly reiterates the call for Setians to contribute their ideas, articles, drawings, and even 'half-finished essays' to The Scroll. This editorial emphasizes that the Scroll's vitality and continued existence depend on member initiative and contributions, reinforcing its role as a dynamic, member-driven platform for Setian thought.

key_concepts.definition: A Left-Hand Path philosophy and practice centered on the Egyptian god Set, emphasizing individual self-deification, intellectual evolution, and the pursuit of unique excellence through personal power and Will.

The central concept of Setianism, meaning 'to come into being,' 'to become,' or 'to create oneself.' It refers to the continuous process of self-transformation, intellectual development, and evolving beyond one's current state of being.
The ongoing process of evolutionary self-transformation and growth characteristic of becoming a Setian, implying a fundamental change in one's being and consciousness.

A spiritual and magical path emphasizing individualism, self-deification, the breaking of conventional taboos, and the pursuit of spiritual insight and power through direct, often unconventional, experience and self-mastery, rather than union with a universal divine.
The organizational body for Setianism, conceived as a dispersed community of unique individuals focused on their personal Xeper, distinct from traditional religious structures.
A comprehensive, looseleaf encyclopedia of magical philosophy for the Temple of Set, accessible to members at the II° (Adept) degree and higher, designed for continuous expansion and revision.

An 'orientation' text specifically for I° (Initiate) members. It provides foundational Setian philosophy, basic guidelines for magic, and addresses areas of philosophy and accuracy beyond older occult texts like The Satanic Bible.

The first degree of membership in the Temple of Set, serving as a 'testing' environment where individuals evaluate the Temple, and the Temple evaluates the individual's raw intelligence, logical analysis, and initiative over a two-year period.

The second degree of membership, a 'confirmation' that the I°'s evaluation process has been successfully passed, signifying intellectual growth and initiative, and granting access to the Ruby Tablet. Recognition requires active engagement with III°+ members and demonstrated Xeper.

Members of the Priesthood (III° and higher degrees) who are empowered to Recognize a Setian as an Adept II°. They evaluate I° members based on their appreciation for the Temple's sophistication, intelligence, initiative, and pursuit of projects.

The official periodical/newsletter of the Temple of Set, designed as a 'free long-distance telephone conference-call' for the entire membership. Its purpose is to foster open discussion, share diverse ideas, and facilitate intellectual exchange, rather than solely dispensing 'approved doctrine.'
Local concentrations of Temple of Set members who gather to interact and pursue common interests, facilitating face-to-face communication and shared activities.

Formal gatherings of Temple of Set members, often regional or national, for social interaction, rituals, discussions, and administrative purposes, serving to build community and facilitate communication across distances.

practical_system.description: The Temple of Set's practical system is designed to facilitate individual self-deification (Xeper) through a structured yet self-directed initiatory path. Progression is achieved by demonstrating raw intelligence, logical analysis, research capabilities, and proactive engagement with the Temple's philosophy and its members, rather than passive adherence. Key components include a tiered degree system (I° Initiate, II° Adept, III°+ Priesthood) with specific expectations and access to increasingly advanced knowledge bases (Crystal Tablet for I°s, Ruby Tablet for II°s). Communication is fostered through a member-driven periodical (The Scroll of Set) and face-to-face gatherings (Pylons, Conclaves), which serve as forums for discussion, ritual, and networking. The system emphasizes personal initiative, continuous learning, and active contribution to the collective body of Setian thought.
tools: The Scroll of Set (periodical for communication and idea exchange)
Ruby Tablet (comprehensive magical philosophy encyclopedia for II°+)
Crystal Tablet (orientation text for I° members, foundational Setian philosophy)
rituals: IV°+ Recognition ritual (for Master of the Temple)
Dark Seance (contextually implied for ceremonial gathering)

relevant_quotes.text: The easiest ones for us to fool are ourselves, because we've had so much practice. The hardest ploys for us to see through are our own rationalizations. To be fully Setian we must see through our own ploys, and stop fooling ourselves. For many of us this may be the hardest step in Setamorphosis.

Setians are to think, to grow, to Xeper. Heretics have thoughts or opinions that differ from established credos. An intellect whose thoughts are deemed intellectually destructive to the Temple of Set is not a heretic but merely removed from the Temple. In other words we have excommunication rather than heresy. Shades of Catholicism! Who decides if we are thinking 'right' thoughts while we are growing? What is 'right'? I strive to Xeper. Set forbid that I should Xeper erroneously.

The Scroll of Set was not and is not and will not be a tool of this kind. Its purpose is dictated by the unique nature of the Temple itself. Because the Temple is made up of a very rare type of individual, our entire membership is stretched out across vast distances.

The Scroll is a free long-distance telephone conference-call that you can make to the entire Temple membership once a month. It does not reflect only 'approved doctrine'; it reflects ideas for consideration and discussion. I know the ideas are out there, 'cause I see copies of brilliant interpersonal letters across my desk every day. The trick is for you to let a few other Setians in on them, that's all.

What we need is a text that will cover roughly the same ground as the Satanic Bible an 'orientation' text, as it were - to Setian standards of accuracy and academic sophistication. And it will have to address many areas of philosophy unknown and/or unappreciated when the Satanic Bible was written.

It is that the initiative for your Recognition rests with you. The III° are willing to help and advise you, but they are not going to seek you out nor do your thinking for you. If the title of Adept of Set II° is to mean what it says, this is the correct course of action. And I think you'll agree.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is crucial for understanding the foundational philosophy and operational mechanics of the Temple of Set during its nascent period. It elucidates core Setian concepts like Xeper and Setamorphosis, distinguishing the organization's approach to spiritual evolution from more traditional occult models. By detailing the initiatory system, the role of internal publications (The Scroll), and administrative structures, it highlights a unique Left Hand Path emphasis on individual initiative, intellectual rigor, and decentralized communication. The article on 'Heresy' in particular showcases the ongoing internal dialogue and refinement of Setian principles in practice, making it a valuable primary source for scholars and practitioners of Western Esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes current and prospective members of the Temple of Set, especially Initiates (I°) seeking to understand the path to Adeptship (II°). It also targets the Priesthood and administrative staff for policy updates and directives. Academics and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Left Hand Path traditions, and new religious movements would find this document highly relevant for historical context, comparative studies of magical orders, and insights into organizational development within occultism.
